column23: Big Tech’s latest earnings have laid out some valuable lessons.If you need more proof that Wall Street’s obsession with AI is still going strong

column2: Has This E-Commerce Stock Entered Bargain Territory?`The last 12 months were a good period in general for e-commerce stocks. Companies like Amazon
column3: Shopify
column4: MercadoLibre
column5: and Pinduoduo saw their share prices rise at least 30%.But the industry had its laggards too
column6: including JD.com (NASDAQ: JD)
column7: which saw its shares fall 61% in the past year. With the stock now down 78% from its all-time high
column8: JD.com has attracted some investors looking to take advantage of a potential bargain.But before you rush into the stock
column9: you should understand how JD.com got here in the first place. Only then can you make an informed investment decision.JD.com is one of the more successful companies replicating Amazon's playbook.The e-commerce giant operates a first-party e-commerce business in China by selling a wide range of products directly to customers. It also operates a third-party marketplace that allows other sellers on its platform
column10: in exchange for fees from each successful transaction.The company emphasizes low prices to encourage customers to buy more over time
column11: and it operates a complex logistics service to offer speedy deliveries. The low prices and fast delivery leads to strong customer retention and sales growth
column12: providing JD.com with the scale needed to drive prices even lower and continuously improve its service.Customers love the approach
column13: which explains the company's uninterrupted growth for many years. For perspective
column14: revenue grew revenue at a compound annual rate of 27% from 2017 to 2021. Everything seemed to be moving in the right direction until recently.Investors accustomed to such an impressive track record were disappointed when the e-commerce company reported just 10% revenue growth in 2022. Subsequent months were even more challenging for the company with revenue growth declining to just 2% in Q3 2023. Revenue from its flagship first-party e-commerce business actually fell 1% year over year
column15: masked by a 13% increase in service revenue.To add salt to the wound
column16: competitor PDD Holdings reported 94% top-line growth in the same quarter. Even Alibaba
column17: which is facing its own challenges
column18: reported 9% growth.JD.com is failing to keep up with the competition. It didn't help that previous CEO Xu Lei stepped down from his post in May 2023 after just one year
column19: adding another layer of uncertainty to the company's future.The silver lining here is the fact the company is still profitable with a strong balance sheet. JD.com generated 39 billion yuan ($5.4 billion) in free cash flow in the 12 months ended Sept. 30
column20: 2023. It also had 242 billion yuan ($33.2 billion) in cash and short-term investments. With this solid financial position
column21: JD.com can continue to invest in areas like live-streaming shopping
column22: supply chain improvements
column23: and other initiatives.Still
column24: investors should be aware the path ahead remains challenging as it will have to outmaneuver rivals like Alibaba
column25: Pinduoduo
column26: and Douyin.So JD.com is at a crossroads. Despite its previous success
column27: the future is far less certain now that it faces a more competitive industry and greater regulatory scrutiny.Given the recent bearish sentiment
column28: JD.com stock trades at a significant discount to other e-commerce companies with a price-to-earnings (PE) ratio is just 10.2
column29: while Pinduoduo trades at 27.8 times earnings.Investors should monitor JD.com's rebound efforts in the coming quarters for clues of its progress. If the company can defend its position as a top three e-commerce platform in China and rekindle growth
column30: its current stock price should prove to be a bargain.Should you invest $1

column1: Jim Cramer Says You Should Stay Away from These 10 Stocks`"In this article

column6: it would be ""too late"" to invest in stocks once the Fed begins to cut interest rates. Jim Cramer said that stocks are in a win-win situation. If the economy keeps growing and the market remains strong

column1: 3 Inspiring Underdogs That Fought Tech Giants and Won`"When it comes to success in emerging industries
column2: size usually matters. Pioneers often fail
column3: leaving behind the foundation for larger players to dominate. Thankfully for investors in mold-breaking upstarts
column4: it doesn't always play out that way.Roku (NASDAQ: ROKU)
column6: and Spotify Technology (NYSE: SPOT) are three companies that saw Apple and other consumer tech behemoths try to take them out. The little guys are not just surviving
column7: but thriving against established titans with almost limitless resources. Take a bow Roku
column8: Sonos
column9: and Spotify.Roku founder Anthony Wood invented the digital video recorder
column10: but it was another company that enjoyed the DVR glory. He got it right when he launched Roku a few years later
column11: pioneering the streaming video revolution. It wasn't long before Roku was joined by some of the most valuable companies on the planet. Apple TV
column12: Alphabet's Google Chromecast
column13: and Amazon's Fire TV hit the market. Roku didn't flinch.Roku remains the leading operating system for smart TVs in the U.S.
column14: Canada
column15: and Mexico. It has roughly double the market share of its closest rival. It doesn't matter that Google and Amazon are willing to practically give away the hardware to get folks connected. Roku has been able to sacrifice product margins
column16: knowing it can make it up in volume.Roku is free to use
column17: making the lion's share of its revenue from ad sharing and referrals. It's working. Average revenue per user is more than $41 over the past year. There are 75.8 million active accounts on the platform
column18: and boy are they active. Roku users are spending an average of 3.8 hours a day streaming through the Roku hub.It doesn't seem possible. Roku is competing against Apple
column19: a company that is used to getting people to pay a premium for its wares. Alphabet is the global leader in online advertising
column20: putting it in the perfect position to cash in on an ad-supported industry. Amazon is the top dog in online retail
column21: and it aggressively promotes its Fire TV dongles and smart TVs on its platform. Roku is still beating them all.Roku's enemies are also rivals of Sonos. It was 2005 when Sonos rolled out the first wireless multiroom speaker system
column22: which streams audio seamlessly through a home. Audiophiles flocked to Sonos
column23: but then familiar foes emerged. Apple
column24: Amazon
column25: and Google all had cheap smart speakers in support of their virtual assistant technologies. Sonos was in their crosshairs if they chose to go upmarket
column26: but they missed.Sonos would go on to deliver 17 consecutive years of revenue growth before proving mortal in fiscal 2023. On Tuesday afternoon it posted financial results for the fiscal first quarter of 2024. It was a well-received report.Revenue declined 9%
column27: or 10.5% on a constant-currency basis. It's not pretty
column28: but analysts were bracing for a 13% decline. The bigger surprise is at the other end of the income statement. Profitability improved at Sonos
column29: earning $0.64 a share for the seasonally potent holiday quarter
column30: up from $0.57 a share a year earlier. Wall Street pros were settling for a sharp decline to $0.39 a share.""Despite the challenging environment
column31: we are winning in the market and outperforming the competition
column32: CEO Patrick Spence said in this week's earnings report.Rich in cash and patents
column33: Sonos is well positioned to continue dominating its high-end niche. With analyst profit targets now likely headed higher
column34: Sonos is cheap.Remember when everyone figured that Spotify was toast? The Swedish audio streaming service was making waves worldwide
column35: but would it be able to succeed in the U.S. as Apple Music
column36: Google Play Music
column37: and Amazon Music flooded the market? It's doing pretty well
column38: even if it had to go through three rounds of layoffs last year.There are 602 million mostly ad-supported monthly active users
column39: a 23% increase over the past year. Getting folks to pay is the more difficult nut to crack
column40: but Spotify has been beefing up its catalog of original content to go with its industry-leading music platform. Premium Spotify accounts have risen 15% over the past year to reach 236 million.Apple and Amazon are distant competitors. Google Play Music threw in the towel
column41: handing its digital ambitions over to YouTube Music. It's going to be hard for the other streaming service stocks to catch up to Spotify now.Should you invest $1

How Twitter's descent into chaos is paving the way for a new web`"The post-Twitter era has spurred the development and further growth of numerous social networks that prioritize brief posts
column2: from open source standbys like Mastodon to new decentralized concepts like Bluesky
column3: and those from smaller startups like Post
column4: Spill
column6: to those from tech giants like Meta
column7: which launched the Twitter-like Threads. While this is great news for people looking for a new place to land after Twitter's demise (the network under Elon Musk is now called X and headed in a different direction)
column8: it's a challenge for early adopters who want to experiment with new apps and services.Not everyone is satisfied with X's current course. Though a top-ranked app today
column9: it's not the Twitter of years past. X takes a lax approach to content moderation
column10: leaving advertisers and some users in search of new options. Even its owner dabbles in antisemitism and trolling
column11: prompting more of the same from the user base. As top advertisers fled
column12: X's ads became worse and more spammy.Elon Musk says ‘go f*ck yourself’ to advertisers leaving XThe changes at X have been swift and troublesome
column13: leading to a flurry of activity in the social sphere as X alternatives emerged. But now there's too much of a good thing.The Twitter diaspora
column14: so to speak
column15: is hungry for a solution to save them from having to browse content from across half a dozen apps
column16: in addition to the news websites
column17: blogs
column18: and other information sources they already consume while online.That problem is now being addressed by another group of developers -- those who aren't trying to re-create Twitter or improve upon it
column19: but solve the problem of there being ""too many Twitters"" to keep up with.Last week
column20: we reported on Tapestry
column21: a new project from The Iconfactory
column22: the app development shop best known for its work on the early Twitter client Twitterrific. Recently funded on Kickstarter after only showing off its prototype build
column23: Tapestry aims to offer a unified app for tracking social media
column24: news

column26: Bluesky
column27: Mastodon
column28: Tumblr
column29: and others in the future
column30: like perhaps Threads.The Iconfactory was only looking to raise $100
column31: 000 to start development of the new app. It was fully funded as of February 5 and has since exceeded that
column32: which allows it to now chase stretch goals of $150
column33: 000 and up
column34: which would fund additional features for the app
column35: like muting
column36: filtering
column37: search
column38: bookmarking
column39: and more.Image Credits: The IconfactoryThe Iconfactory isn't the only developer who has seized on this moment to develop a new multi-service social app.The developer behind the popular Mac and iOS newsreader app Reeder
column40: Silvio Rizzi
column41: is now working on something of a Reeder replacement. Though Rizzi says Reeder will continue to be supported
column42: the new project aims to offer more than just news feeds. In an announcement on Mastodon last week
column43: the developer teased plans for an app that's ""not just an RSS reader
column44: but instead a tool that would allow you to access content from across sources
column45: like ""podcasts
column46: YouTube
column47: Mastodon
column49: he said.The app is expected to launch into public beta later this spring on Mac
column51: and iPad. (A screenshot of the app concept Rizzi posted offered a nod to Tapestry
column52: as both projects emerged around the same time.)Image Credits: Silvio RizziMeanwhile
column53: Tapbots
column54: the makers of Mastodon client Ivory (and previously the Twitter app Tweetbot on which it's based)
column55: is weighing how to approach the growing number of social networks available to users. There is no single Twitter alternative
column56: so deciding where to focus limited developer resources is key.According to Tapbots co-founder Paul Haddad
column57: the company hasn't yet decided whether it will support Bluesky yet
column58: but says they are thinking about it.""We’ve got our next few months pretty booked with Ivory/Mastodon features and of course are committed to the Fediverse long-term
column60: referring to the decentralized social web powered by the ActivityPub protocol. ""We do plan to take a look at Bluesky sometime after that.""However
column61: if Tapbots chooses to support Bluesky
column62: it may or may not be part of the Ivory app
column63: he added.Other services are focused on the needs of power users and creators to cross-post to multiple networks at once. This includes scheduling tools like those from fedica and Postpone
column64: as well as consumer apps like Yup. The latter offers a solution for posting to X
column69: though it lacks access to a Threads developer API
column70: requiring users to disable Instagram’s two-factor authentication (2FA) to get it to work. (We do NOT recommend this.)Image Credits: YupSimilarly
column71: an app from a Japanese developer
column75: and the federated networks Misskey and Firefish.Then there are the various web3
column79: as well as other decentralized protocols that are fostering networks of their own
column80: like Nostr (favored by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey these days). There's also the decentralized network Matrix
column81: which offers multiple cross-platform clients.Even Reddit has inspired decentralized alternatives
column84: and other smaller projects.Because not all the decentralized networks talk to each other
column85: bridges between protocols are also being built
column86: like those that connect Matrix to Nostr or Mastodon to Bluesky
column87: among others.Quipped Columbia Journalism Review journalist and longtime tech early adopter Mathew Ingram in a post on Threads
column88: ""We need a FriendFeed for the 2000s.""His reference recalls a former era of social networking plenty
column90: when users turned to a social networking aggregator co-founded by then-former Googlers Bret Taylor (former Salesforce Co-CEO)
column93: and Sanjeev Singh. FriendFeed brought together social networking websites
column97: and microblogs into one place -- something that's again in demand today following the explosion of Twitter alternatives and decentralized services.Of course
column98: Facebook eventually acquired FriendFeed and began to dominate social media
column99: shutting out even well-resourced competitors like Google+. Now known as Meta
column100: the social networking giant remains unbeaten
column101: with nearly 3.2 billion users across its family of apps. But in its rush to adopt the ActivityPub protocol in its new app Threads
column103: there's a hint of concern. It suggests that even Meta believes the tide could possibly turn against it
column104: as users embrace these alternative social platforms.For some smaller apps
column105: the decision is whether to try to compete with the growing number of alternatives or join them. For instance
column109: the developer of a Twitter analytics service previously
column110: announced in December that his network would ""soon"" integrate with Mastodon for cross-posting and later
column111: Threads.""Users being able to post across various platforms positions Spoutible not just as a social media platform but as a versatile tool designed to streamline your digital communication
column113: after it was clear Spoutible was not among those favored to win the competition to be the new Twitter.Unfortunately for people in hopes of a simple cross-posting solution
column114: Spoutible this month faced security issues when it was revealed the API had a serious vulnerability that could allow hackers to take control of user accounts. The API even returned users' 2FA (two-factor authentication) code and the reset tokens that helped users change passwords. That puts Spoutible's cross-posting plans on the back burner for the time being
column115: if not its future altogether.Another Web 2.0 survivor
column117: also recently decided integration was the best path forward. It ditched Twitter and integrated with Mastodon while rebuilding its backend to join the fediverse -- the decentralized social web. The social magazine app also became the first app to support Bluesky
column119: and Pixelfed (a decentralized Instagram alternative) last May
column120: allowing users to track updates across these social networks
column122: all in one place.Image Credits: FlipboardAnother platform
column124: is looking to address the cross-posting needs from a different angle: as the blog host. Instead of creating content directly on social platforms
column128: while also still cross-posting to more popular platforms including Mastodon
column135: and Pixelfed. (The Iconfactory said its forthcoming app Tapestry would also support micro.blog).Elsewhere
column136: publishing giant WordPress acquired an ActivityPub plugin to allow WordPress blogs to join the fediverse. Newsletter platform Substack created a short-form ""Notes"" feed that resembled Twitter. Artifact
column138: eventually pivoted to cloning Twitter before shutting down.In short
column139: a lot is going on in the social web today. And this is by no means a definitive list of those companies and developers attacking the problem -- or adding to it. Unnamed are
column141: the wide variety of open source and smaller projects in the works
column143: as is common when open APIs are available.Whether this explosion of new social networks is a temporary problem or a new state of being remains to be seen. Likely
column144: some of the smaller ""Twitter-alts"" will eventually die off
column146: or will fold into the wider fediverse
column147: as the would-be Twitter rival Pebble (formerly T2) did last year.But it's also possible that we're witnessing the rebuilding of the web in real time. One where there are many protocols
column149: and many ways to connect not just people
column154: and blogs.Aggregators like Tapestry may be an initial step to figuring out how to navigate this new web
column155: but it also calls out for a way to search it too: a new Google of sorts that plugs into all the activity now taking place beyond websites
column156: including the information that's shared through these novel social networks across new protocols. And who is building that?Twitterrific’s team is back with Tapestry
column157: an app for tracking social media
column159: RSS and moreAs Bluesky opens to the public

column4: Apple and TikTok and two very large online search engines.The size of the annual fee is related to the number of average monthly active users for each company and whether it posts a profit or loss in the preceding financial year.Meta said it disagreed with the methodology used to calculate the fees.""Currently

column1: Meta accused of not taking Facebook Marketplace fraud seriously`Meta has been accused by MPs of not taking the problem of online fraud on its platforms seriously.The parent company of Facebook and Instagram came under scrutiny from the Home Affairs Select Committee after representatives from the banking sector said the “majority” of scams they see start on Meta platforms.Paul Davis
column2: financial crime prevention director at TSB

column4: which

column7: which as I say are the main ones
column8: we see about 80% start on social media

column10: let’s not walk past the fact that
column11: when I say social media there
column12: the majority of them start from the channels owned by one company in particular

column14: 2024He added: “Facebook Marketplace doesn’t have a payments channel attached to it

column16: for example

column20: Philip Milton

column1: 3 Inspiring Underdogs That Fought Tech Giants and Won`"When it comes to success in emerging industries
column2: size usually matters. Pioneers often fail
column3: leaving behind the foundation for larger players to dominate. Thankfully for investors in mold-breaking upstarts
column4: it doesn't always play out that way.Roku (NASDAQ: ROKU)
column6: and Spotify Technology (NYSE: SPOT) are three companies that saw Apple and other consumer tech behemoths try to take them out. The little guys are not just surviving
column7: but thriving against established titans with almost limitless resources. Take a bow Roku
column8: Sonos
column9: and Spotify.Roku founder Anthony Wood invented the digital video recorder
column10: but it was another company that enjoyed the DVR glory. He got it right when he launched Roku a few years later
column11: pioneering the streaming video revolution. It wasn't long before Roku was joined by some of the most valuable companies on the planet. Apple TV
column12: Alphabet's Google Chromecast
column13: and Amazon's Fire TV hit the market. Roku didn't flinch.Roku remains the leading operating system for smart TVs in the U.S.
column14: Canada
column15: and Mexico. It has roughly double the market share of its closest rival. It doesn't matter that Google and Amazon are willing to practically give away the hardware to get folks connected. Roku has been able to sacrifice product margins
column16: knowing it can make it up in volume.Roku is free to use
column17: making the lion's share of its revenue from ad sharing and referrals. It's working. Average revenue per user is more than $41 over the past year. There are 75.8 million active accounts on the platform
column18: and boy are they active. Roku users are spending an average of 3.8 hours a day streaming through the Roku hub.It doesn't seem possible. Roku is competing against Apple
column19: a company that is used to getting people to pay a premium for its wares. Alphabet is the global leader in online advertising
column20: putting it in the perfect position to cash in on an ad-supported industry. Amazon is the top dog in online retail
column21: and it aggressively promotes its Fire TV dongles and smart TVs on its platform. Roku is still beating them all.Roku's enemies are also rivals of Sonos. It was 2005 when Sonos rolled out the first wireless multiroom speaker system
column22: which streams audio seamlessly through a home. Audiophiles flocked to Sonos
column23: but then familiar foes emerged. Apple
column24: Amazon
column25: and Google all had cheap smart speakers in support of their virtual assistant technologies. Sonos was in their crosshairs if they chose to go upmarket
column26: but they missed.Sonos would go on to deliver 17 consecutive years of revenue growth before proving mortal in fiscal 2023. On Tuesday afternoon it posted financial results for the fiscal first quarter of 2024. It was a well-received report.Revenue declined 9%
column27: or 10.5% on a constant-currency basis. It's not pretty
column28: but analysts were bracing for a 13% decline. The bigger surprise is at the other end of the income statement. Profitability improved at Sonos
column29: earning $0.64 a share for the seasonally potent holiday quarter
column30: up from $0.57 a share a year earlier. Wall Street pros were settling for a sharp decline to $0.39 a share.""Despite the challenging environment
column31: we are winning in the market and outperforming the competition
column32: CEO Patrick Spence said in this week's earnings report.Rich in cash and patents
column33: Sonos is well positioned to continue dominating its high-end niche. With analyst profit targets now likely headed higher
column34: Sonos is cheap.Remember when everyone figured that Spotify was toast? The Swedish audio streaming service was making waves worldwide
column35: but would it be able to succeed in the U.S. as Apple Music
column36: Google Play Music
column37: and Amazon Music flooded the market? It's doing pretty well
column38: even if it had to go through three rounds of layoffs last year.There are 602 million mostly ad-supported monthly active users

column40: but Spotify has been beefing up its catalog of original content to go with its industry-leading music platform. Premium Spotify accounts have risen 15% over the past year to reach 236 million.Apple and Amazon are distant competitors. Google Play Music threw in the towel
column41: handing its digital ambitions over to YouTube Music. It's going to be hard for the other streaming service stocks to catch up to Spotify now.Should you invest $1

How Twitter's descent into chaos is paving the way for a new web`"The post-Twitter era has spurred the development and further growth of numerous social networks that prioritize brief posts
column2: from open source standbys like Mastodon to new decentralized concepts like Bluesky
column3: and those from smaller startups like Post
column4: Spill
column6: to those from tech giants like Meta
column7: which launched the Twitter-like Threads. While this is great news for people looking for a new place to land after Twitter's demise (the network under Elon Musk is now called X and headed in a different direction)
column8: it's a challenge for early adopters who want to experiment with new apps and services.Not everyone is satisfied with X's current course. Though a top-ranked app today
column9: it's not the Twitter of years past. X takes a lax approach to content moderation
column10: leaving advertisers and some users in search of new options. Even its owner dabbles in antisemitism and trolling
column11: prompting more of the same from the user base. As top advertisers fled
column12: X's ads became worse and more spammy.Elon Musk says ‘go f*ck yourself’ to advertisers leaving XThe changes at X have been swift and troublesome

column14: so to speak

column16: in addition to the news websites
column17: blogs
column18: and other information sources they already consume while online.That problem is now being addressed by another group of developers -- those who aren't trying to re-create Twitter or improve upon it

column20: we reported on Tapestry

column22: the app development shop best known for its work on the early Twitter client Twitterrific. Recently funded on Kickstarter after only showing off its prototype build

column26: Bluesky
column27: Mastodon

column32: which allows it to now chase stretch goals of $150
column33: 000 and up

column35: like muting
column36: filtering
column37: search

column39: and more.Image Credits: The IconfactoryThe Iconfactory isn't the only developer who has seized on this moment to develop a new multi-service social app.The developer behind the popular Mac and iOS newsreader app Reeder

column42: the new project aims to offer more than just news feeds. In an announcement on Mastodon last week
column43: the developer teased plans for an app that's ""not just an RSS reader
column44: but instead a tool that would allow you to access content from across sources
column45: like ""podcasts
column46: YouTube
column47: Mastodon
column49: he said.The app is expected to launch into public beta later this spring on Mac
column51: and iPad. (A screenshot of the app concept Rizzi posted offered a nod to Tapestry
column52: as both projects emerged around the same time.)Image Credits: Silvio RizziMeanwhile
column53: Tapbots
column54: the makers of Mastodon client Ivory (and previously the Twitter app Tweetbot on which it's based)
column55: is weighing how to approach the growing number of social networks available to users. There is no single Twitter alternative
column56: so deciding where to focus limited developer resources is key.According to Tapbots co-founder Paul Haddad
column57: the company hasn't yet decided whether it will support Bluesky yet
column58: but says they are thinking about it.""We’ve got our next few months pretty booked with Ivory/Mastodon features and of course are committed to the Fediverse long-term
column60: referring to the decentralized social web powered by the ActivityPub protocol. ""We do plan to take a look at Bluesky sometime after that.""However
column61: if Tapbots chooses to support Bluesky
column62: it may or may not be part of the Ivory app
column63: he added.Other services are focused on the needs of power users and creators to cross-post to multiple networks at once. This includes scheduling tools like those from fedica and Postpone
column64: as well as consumer apps like Yup. The latter offers a solution for posting to X
column69: though it lacks access to a Threads developer API
column70: requiring users to disable Instagram’s two-factor authentication (2FA) to get it to work. (We do NOT recommend this.)Image Credits: YupSimilarly
column71: an app from a Japanese developer
column75: and the federated networks Misskey and Firefish.Then there are the various web3
column79: as well as other decentralized protocols that are fostering networks of their own
column80: like Nostr (favored by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey these days). There's also the decentralized network Matrix
column81: which offers multiple cross-platform clients.Even Reddit has inspired decentralized alternatives
column84: and other smaller projects.Because not all the decentralized networks talk to each other
column85: bridges between protocols are also being built
column86: like those that connect Matrix to Nostr or Mastodon to Bluesky
column87: among others.Quipped Columbia Journalism Review journalist and longtime tech early adopter Mathew Ingram in a post on Threads
column88: ""We need a FriendFeed for the 2000s.""His reference recalls a former era of social networking plenty
column90: when users turned to a social networking aggregator co-founded by then-former Googlers Bret Taylor (former Salesforce Co-CEO)
column93: and Sanjeev Singh. FriendFeed brought together social networking websites
column97: and microblogs into one place -- something that's again in demand today following the explosion of Twitter alternatives and decentralized services.Of course
column98: Facebook eventually acquired FriendFeed and began to dominate social media
column99: shutting out even well-resourced competitors like Google+. Now known as Meta
column100: the social networking giant remains unbeaten
column101: with nearly 3.2 billion users across its family of apps. But in its rush to adopt the ActivityPub protocol in its new app Threads
column103: there's a hint of concern. It suggests that even Meta believes the tide could possibly turn against it
column104: as users embrace these alternative social platforms.For some smaller apps
column105: the decision is whether to try to compete with the growing number of alternatives or join them. For instance
column109: the developer of a Twitter analytics service previously
column110: announced in December that his network would ""soon"" integrate with Mastodon for cross-posting and later
column111: Threads.""Users being able to post across various platforms positions Spoutible not just as a social media platform but as a versatile tool designed to streamline your digital communication
column113: after it was clear Spoutible was not among those favored to win the competition to be the new Twitter.Unfortunately for people in hopes of a simple cross-posting solution
column114: Spoutible this month faced security issues when it was revealed the API had a serious vulnerability that could allow hackers to take control of user accounts. The API even returned users' 2FA (two-factor authentication) code and the reset tokens that helped users change passwords. That puts Spoutible's cross-posting plans on the back burner for the time being
column115: if not its future altogether.Another Web 2.0 survivor
column117: also recently decided integration was the best path forward. It ditched Twitter and integrated with Mastodon while rebuilding its backend to join the fediverse -- the decentralized social web. The social magazine app also became the first app to support Bluesky
column119: and Pixelfed (a decentralized Instagram alternative) last May
column120: allowing users to track updates across these social networks
column122: all in one place.Image Credits: FlipboardAnother platform
column124: is looking to address the cross-posting needs from a different angle: as the blog host. Instead of creating content directly on social platforms
column128: while also still cross-posting to more popular platforms including Mastodon
column135: and Pixelfed. (The Iconfactory said its forthcoming app Tapestry would also support micro.blog).Elsewhere
column136: publishing giant WordPress acquired an ActivityPub plugin to allow WordPress blogs to join the fediverse. Newsletter platform Substack created a short-form ""Notes"" feed that resembled Twitter. Artifact
column138: eventually pivoted to cloning Twitter before shutting down.In short
column139: a lot is going on in the social web today. And this is by no means a definitive list of those companies and developers attacking the problem -- or adding to it. Unnamed are
column141: the wide variety of open source and smaller projects in the works
column143: as is common when open APIs are available.Whether this explosion of new social networks is a temporary problem or a new state of being remains to be seen. Likely
column144: some of the smaller ""Twitter-alts"" will eventually die off
column146: or will fold into the wider fediverse
column147: as the would-be Twitter rival Pebble (formerly T2) did last year.But it's also possible that we're witnessing the rebuilding of the web in real time. One where there are many protocols
column149: and many ways to connect not just people
column154: and blogs.Aggregators like Tapestry may be an initial step to figuring out how to navigate this new web
column155: but it also calls out for a way to search it too: a new Google of sorts that plugs into all the activity now taking place beyond websites
column156: including the information that's shared through these novel social networks across new protocols. And who is building that?Twitterrific’s team is back with Tapestry
column157: an app for tracking social media

column1: Jim Cramer Says You Should Stay Away from These 10 Stocks`"In this article

column6: it would be ""too late"" to invest in stocks once the Fed begins to cut interest rates. Jim Cramer said that stocks are in a win-win situation. If the economy keeps growing and the market remains strong

column1: 3 Inspiring Underdogs That Fought Tech Giants and Won`"When it comes to success in emerging industries
column2: size usually matters. Pioneers often fail
column3: leaving behind the foundation for larger players to dominate. Thankfully for investors in mold-breaking upstarts
column4: it doesn't always play out that way.Roku (NASDAQ: ROKU)
column6: and Spotify Technology (NYSE: SPOT) are three companies that saw Apple and other consumer tech behemoths try to take them out. The little guys are not just surviving
column7: but thriving against established titans with almost limitless resources. Take a bow Roku
column8: Sonos
column9: and Spotify.Roku founder Anthony Wood invented the digital video recorder
column10: but it was another company that enjoyed the DVR glory. He got it right when he launched Roku a few years later
column11: pioneering the streaming video revolution. It wasn't long before Roku was joined by some of the most valuable companies on the planet. Apple TV
column12: Alphabet's Google Chromecast
column13: and Amazon's Fire TV hit the market. Roku didn't flinch.Roku remains the leading operating system for smart TVs in the U.S.
column14: Canada
column15: and Mexico. It has roughly double the market share of its closest rival. It doesn't matter that Google and Amazon are willing to practically give away the hardware to get folks connected. Roku has been able to sacrifice product margins
column16: knowing it can make it up in volume.Roku is free to use
column17: making the lion's share of its revenue from ad sharing and referrals. It's working. Average revenue per user is more than $41 over the past year. There are 75.8 million active accounts on the platform
column18: and boy are they active. Roku users are spending an average of 3.8 hours a day streaming through the Roku hub.It doesn't seem possible. Roku is competing against Apple
column19: a company that is used to getting people to pay a premium for its wares. Alphabet is the global leader in online advertising
column20: putting it in the perfect position to cash in on an ad-supported industry. Amazon is the top dog in online retail
column21: and it aggressively promotes its Fire TV dongles and smart TVs on its platform. Roku is still beating them all.Roku's enemies are also rivals of Sonos. It was 2005 when Sonos rolled out the first wireless multiroom speaker system
column22: which streams audio seamlessly through a home. Audiophiles flocked to Sonos
column23: but then familiar foes emerged. Apple
column24: Amazon
column25: and Google all had cheap smart speakers in support of their virtual assistant technologies. Sonos was in their crosshairs if they chose to go upmarket
column26: but they missed.Sonos would go on to deliver 17 consecutive years of revenue growth before proving mortal in fiscal 2023. On Tuesday afternoon it posted financial results for the fiscal first quarter of 2024. It was a well-received report.Revenue declined 9%
column27: or 10.5% on a constant-currency basis. It's not pretty
column28: but analysts were bracing for a 13% decline. The bigger surprise is at the other end of the income statement. Profitability improved at Sonos
column29: earning $0.64 a share for the seasonally potent holiday quarter
column30: up from $0.57 a share a year earlier. Wall Street pros were settling for a sharp decline to $0.39 a share.""Despite the challenging environment
column31: we are winning in the market and outperforming the competition
column32: CEO Patrick Spence said in this week's earnings report.Rich in cash and patents
column33: Sonos is well positioned to continue dominating its high-end niche. With analyst profit targets now likely headed higher
column34: Sonos is cheap.Remember when everyone figured that Spotify was toast? The Swedish audio streaming service was making waves worldwide
column35: but would it be able to succeed in the U.S. as Apple Music
column36: Google Play Music
column37: and Amazon Music flooded the market? It's doing pretty well
column38: even if it had to go through three rounds of layoffs last year.There are 602 million mostly ad-supported monthly active users

column40: but Spotify has been beefing up its catalog of original content to go with its industry-leading music platform. Premium Spotify accounts have risen 15% over the past year to reach 236 million.Apple and Amazon are distant competitors. Google Play Music threw in the towel
column41: handing its digital ambitions over to YouTube Music. It's going to be hard for the other streaming service stocks to catch up to Spotify now.Should you invest $1

How Twitter's descent into chaos is paving the way for a new web`"The post-Twitter era has spurred the development and further growth of numerous social networks that prioritize brief posts
column2: from open source standbys like Mastodon to new decentralized concepts like Bluesky
column3: and those from smaller startups like Post
column4: Spill
column6: to those from tech giants like Meta
column7: which launched the Twitter-like Threads. While this is great news for people looking for a new place to land after Twitter's demise (the network under Elon Musk is now called X and headed in a different direction)
column8: it's a challenge for early adopters who want to experiment with new apps and services.Not everyone is satisfied with X's current course. Though a top-ranked app today
column9: it's not the Twitter of years past. X takes a lax approach to content moderation
column10: leaving advertisers and some users in search of new options. Even its owner dabbles in antisemitism and trolling
column11: prompting more of the same from the user base. As top advertisers fled
column12: X's ads became worse and more spammy.Elon Musk says ‘go f*ck yourself’ to advertisers leaving XThe changes at X have been swift and troublesome

column14: so to speak

column16: in addition to the news websites

column20: we reported on Tapestry

column32: which allows it to now chase stretch goals of $150
column33: 000 and up

column35: like muting
column36: filtering

column46: YouTube
column47: Mastodon
column49: he said.The app is expected to launch into public beta later this spring on Mac

column53: Tapbots

column55: is weighing how to approach the growing number of social networks available to users. There is no single Twitter alternative

column58: but says they are thinking about it.""We’ve got our next few months pretty booked with Ivory/Mastodon features and of course are committed to the Fediverse long-term
column60: referring to the decentralized social web powered by the ActivityPub protocol. ""We do plan to take a look at Bluesky sometime after that.""However
column61: if Tapbots chooses to support Bluesky
column62: it may or may not be part of the Ivory app
column63: he added.Other services are focused on the needs of power users and creators to cross-post to multiple networks at once. This includes scheduling tools like those from fedica and Postpone
column64: as well as consumer apps like Yup. The latter offers a solution for posting to X
column69: though it lacks access to a Threads developer API
column70: requiring users to disable Instagram’s two-factor authentication (2FA) to get it to work. (We do NOT recommend this.)Image Credits: YupSimilarly
column71: an app from a Japanese developer
column75: and the federated networks Misskey and Firefish.Then there are the various web3
column79: as well as other decentralized protocols that are fostering networks of their own
column80: like Nostr (favored by Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey these days). There's also the decentralized network Matrix
column81: which offers multiple cross-platform clients.Even Reddit has inspired decentralized alternatives
column84: and other smaller projects.Because not all the decentralized networks talk to each other
column85: bridges between protocols are also being built
column86: like those that connect Matrix to Nostr or Mastodon to Bluesky
column87: among others.Quipped Columbia Journalism Review journalist and longtime tech early adopter Mathew Ingram in a post on Threads
column88: ""We need a FriendFeed for the 2000s.""His reference recalls a former era of social networking plenty
column90: when users turned to a social networking aggregator co-founded by then-former Googlers Bret Taylor (former Salesforce Co-CEO)
column93: and Sanjeev Singh. FriendFeed brought together social networking websites
column97: and microblogs into one place -- something that's again in demand today following the explosion of Twitter alternatives and decentralized services.Of course
column98: Facebook eventually acquired FriendFeed and began to dominate social media
column99: shutting out even well-resourced competitors like Google+. Now known as Meta
column100: the social networking giant remains unbeaten
column101: with nearly 3.2 billion users across its family of apps. But in its rush to adopt the ActivityPub protocol in its new app Threads
column103: there's a hint of concern. It suggests that even Meta believes the tide could possibly turn against it
column104: as users embrace these alternative social platforms.For some smaller apps
column105: the decision is whether to try to compete with the growing number of alternatives or join them. For instance
column109: the developer of a Twitter analytics service previously
column110: announced in December that his network would ""soon"" integrate with Mastodon for cross-posting and later
column111: Threads.""Users being able to post across various platforms positions Spoutible not just as a social media platform but as a versatile tool designed to streamline your digital communication
column113: after it was clear Spoutible was not among those favored to win the competition to be the new Twitter.Unfortunately for people in hopes of a simple cross-posting solution
column114: Spoutible this month faced security issues when it was revealed the API had a serious vulnerability that could allow hackers to take control of user accounts. The API even returned users' 2FA (two-factor authentication) code and the reset tokens that helped users change passwords. That puts Spoutible's cross-posting plans on the back burner for the time being
column115: if not its future altogether.Another Web 2.0 survivor
column117: also recently decided integration was the best path forward. It ditched Twitter and integrated with Mastodon while rebuilding its backend to join the fediverse -- the decentralized social web. The social magazine app also became the first app to support Bluesky
column119: and Pixelfed (a decentralized Instagram alternative) last May
column120: allowing users to track updates across these social networks
column122: all in one place.Image Credits: FlipboardAnother platform
column124: is looking to address the cross-posting needs from a different angle: as the blog host. Instead of creating content directly on social platforms
column128: while also still cross-posting to more popular platforms including Mastodon
column135: and Pixelfed. (The Iconfactory said its forthcoming app Tapestry would also support micro.blog).Elsewhere
column136: publishing giant WordPress acquired an ActivityPub plugin to allow WordPress blogs to join the fediverse. Newsletter platform Substack created a short-form ""Notes"" feed that resembled Twitter. Artifact
column138: eventually pivoted to cloning Twitter before shutting down.In short
column139: a lot is going on in the social web today. And this is by no means a definitive list of those companies and developers attacking the problem -- or adding to it. Unnamed are
column141: the wide variety of open source and smaller projects in the works
column143: as is common when open APIs are available.Whether this explosion of new social networks is a temporary problem or a new state of being remains to be seen. Likely
column144: some of the smaller ""Twitter-alts"" will eventually die off
column146: or will fold into the wider fediverse
column147: as the would-be Twitter rival Pebble (formerly T2) did last year.But it's also possible that we're witnessing the rebuilding of the web in real time. One where there are many protocols
column149: and many ways to connect not just people
column154: and blogs.Aggregators like Tapestry may be an initial step to figuring out how to navigate this new web
column155: but it also calls out for a way to search it too: a new Google of sorts that plugs into all the activity now taking place beyond websites
column156: including the information that's shared through these novel social networks across new protocols. And who is building that?Twitterrific’s team is back with Tapestry

column1: 3 Inspiring Underdogs That Fought Tech Giants and Won`"When it comes to success in emerging industries
column2: size usually matters. Pioneers often fail
column3: leaving behind the foundation for larger players to dominate. Thankfully for investors in mold-breaking upstarts
column4: it doesn't always play out that way.Roku (NASDAQ: ROKU)
column6: and Spotify Technology (NYSE: SPOT) are three companies that saw Apple and other consumer tech behemoths try to take them out. The little guys are not just surviving
column7: but thriving against established titans with almost limitless resources. Take a bow Roku
column8: Sonos
column9: and Spotify.Roku founder Anthony Wood invented the digital video recorder
column10: but it was another company that enjoyed the DVR glory. He got it right when he launched Roku a few years later
column11: pioneering the streaming video revolution. It wasn't long before Roku was joined by some of the most valuable companies on the planet. Apple TV
column12: Alphabet's Google Chromecast
column13: and Amazon's Fire TV hit the market. Roku didn't flinch.Roku remains the leading operating system for smart TVs in the U.S.
column14: Canada
column15: and Mexico. It has roughly double the market share of its closest rival. It doesn't matter that Google and Amazon are willing to practically give away the hardware to get folks connected. Roku has been able to sacrifice product margins
column16: knowing it can make it up in volume.Roku is free to use
column17: making the lion's share of its revenue from ad sharing and referrals. It's working. Average revenue per user is more than $41 over the past year. There are 75.8 million active accounts on the platform
column18: and boy are they active. Roku users are spending an average of 3.8 hours a day streaming through the Roku hub.It doesn't seem possible. Roku is competing against Apple
column19: a company that is used to getting people to pay a premium for its wares. Alphabet is the global leader in online advertising
column20: putting it in the perfect position to cash in on an ad-supported industry. Amazon is the top dog in online retail
column21: and it aggressively promotes its Fire TV dongles and smart TVs on its platform. Roku is still beating them all.Roku's enemies are also rivals of Sonos. It was 2005 when Sonos rolled out the first wireless multiroom speaker system
column22: which streams audio seamlessly through a home. Audiophiles flocked to Sonos
column23: but then familiar foes emerged. Apple
column24: Amazon
column25: and Google all had cheap smart speakers in support of their virtual assistant technologies. Sonos was in their crosshairs if they chose to go upmarket
column26: but they missed.Sonos would go on to deliver 17 consecutive years of revenue growth before proving mortal in fiscal 2023. On Tuesday afternoon it posted financial results for the fiscal first quarter of 2024. It was a well-received report.Revenue declined 9%
column27: or 10.5% on a constant-currency basis. It's not pretty
column28: but analysts were bracing for a 13% decline. The bigger surprise is at the other end of the income statement. Profitability improved at Sonos
column29: earning $0.64 a share for the seasonally potent holiday quarter
column30: up from $0.57 a share a year earlier. Wall Street pros were settling for a sharp decline to $0.39 a share.""Despite the challenging environment
column31: we are winning in the market and outperforming the competition
column32: CEO Patrick Spence said in this week's earnings report.Rich in cash and patents
column33: Sonos is well positioned to continue dominating its high-end niche. With analyst profit targets now likely headed higher
column34: Sonos is cheap.Remember when everyone figured that Spotify was toast? The Swedish audio streaming service was making waves worldwide
column35: but would it be able to succeed in the U.S. as Apple Music
column36: Google Play Music
column37: and Amazon Music flooded the market? It's doing pretty well
column38: even if it had to go through three rounds of layoffs last year.There are 602 million mostly ad-supported monthly active users
column39: a 23% increase over the past year. Getting folks to pay is the more difficult nut to crack
column40: but Spotify has been beefing up its catalog of original content to go with its industry-leading music platform. Premium Spotify accounts have risen 15% over the past year to reach 236 million.Apple and Amazon are distant competitors. Google Play Music threw in the towel
column41: handing its digital ambitions over to YouTube Music. It's going to be hard for the other streaming service stocks to catch up to Spotify now.Should you invest $1

column6: Amazon (AMZN)

column15: Meta

column17: meanwhile

column23: Big Tech’s latest earnings have laid out some valuable lessons.If you need more proof that Wall Street’s obsession with AI is still going strong

column28: meanwhile
column29: said that Microsoft’s AI-powered Copilots are drawing plenty of interest from enterprise customers. Microsoft’s Copilots are essentially AI-powered apps and include Copilot for Microsoft 365 and the Windows Copilot
column30: which now comes installed on Windows 11 computers.“Copilot conversions appear to be exploding across the MSFT ecosystem as the AI Revolution has begun with partners/customers lining up for the Copilot deployments
column31: ” Ives wrote in a note.Microsoft wasn’t the only company to call out AI. Amazon debuted its new Rufus generative AI shopping bot just ahead of earnings
column32: helping the company better illustrate how generative AI fits into its consumer offerings.Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai also brought up his company’s AI investments at the top of its earnings call
column33: laying out how the technology is being integrated into Google Search

column36: every creator will have an AI that their community can engage with
column37: every business will have an AI that their customers can interact with to buy goods and get support
column38: and every developer will have a state-of-the-art open-source model to build with
column39: ” Zuckerberg said during his company’s earnings call.Intel and AMD
column40: meanwhile

column43: ” Cook said during the call.""I think there is a huge opportunity for Apple with [generative] AI and AI
column44: he later added in response to an analyst's question.We’ll likely learn more about Apple’s AI moves during its Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) in June. Investors hope the technology will provide a boost to iPhone sales by adding new features that get customers itching to upgrade.While AI continues to drive much of the conversation around Big Tech earnings
column45: this season also taught us that business fundamentals are still key to driving share prices on Wall Street.Alphabet and Apple proved that the hard way.While both companies beat analysts’ expectations on the top and bottom lines

column52: investors clearly were

column55: it’ll prove both of this earnings season’s lessons true.Daniel Howley is the tech editor at Yahoo Finance. He's been covering the tech industry since 2011. You can follow him on Twitter @DanielHowley.For the latest earnings reports and analysis

column2: and though AI chip giant Nvidia (NVDA) won’t report its results until Feb. 21

column28: meanwhile

column31: ” Ives wrote in a note.Microsoft wasn’t the only company to call out AI. Amazon debuted its new Rufus generative AI shopping bot just ahead of earnings

column33: laying out how the technology is being integrated into Google Search

column39: ” Zuckerberg said during his company’s earnings call.Intel and AMD
column40: meanwhile

column43: ” Cook said during the call.""I think there is a huge opportunity for Apple with [generative] AI and AI
column44: he later added in response to an analyst's question.We’ll likely learn more about Apple’s AI moves during its Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) in June. Investors hope the technology will provide a boost to iPhone sales by adding new features that get customers itching to upgrade.While AI continues to drive much of the conversation around Big Tech earnings

column2: Has This E-Commerce Stock Entered Bargain Territory?`The last 12 months were a good period in general for e-commerce stocks. Companies like Amazon
column3: Shopify

column6: including JD.com (NASDAQ: JD)
column7: which saw its shares fall 61% in the past year. With the stock now down 78% from its all-time high
column8: JD.com has attracted some investors looking to take advantage of a potential bargain.But before you rush into the stock
column9: you should understand how JD.com got here in the first place. Only then can you make an informed investment decision.JD.com is one of the more successful companies replicating Amazon's playbook.The e-commerce giant operates a first-party e-commerce business in China by selling a wide range of products directly to customers. It also operates a third-party marketplace that allows other sellers on its platform
column10: in exchange for fees from each successful transaction.The company emphasizes low prices to encourage customers to buy more over time
column11: and it operates a complex logistics service to offer speedy deliveries. The low prices and fast delivery leads to strong customer retention and sales growth
column12: providing JD.com with the scale needed to drive prices even lower and continuously improve its service.Customers love the approach
column13: which explains the company's uninterrupted growth for many years. For perspective
column14: revenue grew revenue at a compound annual rate of 27% from 2017 to 2021. Everything seemed to be moving in the right direction until recently.Investors accustomed to such an impressive track record were disappointed when the e-commerce company reported just 10% revenue growth in 2022. Subsequent months were even more challenging for the company with revenue growth declining to just 2% in Q3 2023. Revenue from its flagship first-party e-commerce business actually fell 1% year over year
column15: masked by a 13% increase in service revenue.To add salt to the wound
column16: competitor PDD Holdings reported 94% top-line growth in the same quarter. Even Alibaba
column17: which is facing its own challenges
column18: reported 9% growth.JD.com is failing to keep up with the competition. It didn't help that previous CEO Xu Lei stepped down from his post in May 2023 after just one year
column19: adding another layer of uncertainty to the company's future.The silver lining here is the fact the company is still profitable with a strong balance sheet. JD.com generated 39 billion yuan ($5.4 billion) in free cash flow in the 12 months ended Sept. 30
column20: 2023. It also had 242 billion yuan ($33.2 billion) in cash and short-term investments. With this solid financial position
column21: JD.com can continue to invest in areas like live-streaming shopping
column22: supply chain improvements
column23: and other initiatives.Still
column24: investors should be aware the path ahead remains challenging as it will have to outmaneuver rivals like Alibaba
column25: Pinduoduo
column26: and Douyin.So JD.com is at a crossroads. Despite its previous success
column27: the future is far less certain now that it faces a more competitive industry and greater regulatory scrutiny.Given the recent bearish sentiment
column28: JD.com stock trades at a significant discount to other e-commerce companies with a price-to-earnings (PE) ratio is just 10.2
column29: while Pinduoduo trades at 27.8 times earnings.Investors should monitor JD.com's rebound efforts in the coming quarters for clues of its progress. If the company can defend its position as a top three e-commerce platform in China and rekindle growth
column30: its current stock price should prove to be a bargain.Should you invest $1

Cramer wondered how and why the Fed would cut interest rates when strong employment numbers keep coming and inflation is also not going down significantly.Jim Cramer tried to convince his viewers to invest in the stock market and said that while it would seem ""reckless"" to invest in the stock market because of the risks involved
column6: it would be ""too late"" to invest in stocks once the Fed begins to cut interest rates. Jim Cramer said that stocks are in a win-win situation. If the economy keeps growing and the market remains strong

column1: 3 Inspiring Underdogs That Fought Tech Giants and Won`"When it comes to success in emerging industries
column2: size usually matters. Pioneers often fail
column3: leaving behind the foundation for larger players to dominate. Thankfully for investors in mold-breaking upstarts
column4: it doesn't always play out that way.Roku (NASDAQ: ROKU)
column6: and Spotify Technology (NYSE: SPOT) are three companies that saw Apple and other consumer tech behemoths try to take them out. The little guys are not just surviving
column7: but thriving against established titans with almost limitless resources. Take a bow Roku
column8: Sonos
column9: and Spotify.Roku founder Anthony Wood invented the digital video recorder
column10: but it was another company that enjoyed the DVR glory. He got it right when he launched Roku a few years later
column11: pioneering the streaming video revolution. It wasn't long before Roku was joined by some of the most valuable companies on the planet. Apple TV
column12: Alphabet's Google Chromecast
column13: and Amazon's Fire TV hit the market. Roku didn't flinch.Roku remains the leading operating system for smart TVs in the U.S.
column14: Canada
column15: and Mexico. It has roughly double the market share of its closest rival. It doesn't matter that Google and Amazon are willing to practically give away the hardware to get folks connected. Roku has been able to sacrifice product margins
column16: knowing it can make it up in volume.Roku is free to use
column17: making the lion's share of its revenue from ad sharing and referrals. It's working. Average revenue per user is more than $41 over the past year. There are 75.8 million active accounts on the platform
column18: and boy are they active. Roku users are spending an average of 3.8 hours a day streaming through the Roku hub.It doesn't seem possible. Roku is competing against Apple
column19: a company that is used to getting people to pay a premium for its wares. Alphabet is the global leader in online advertising
column20: putting it in the perfect position to cash in on an ad-supported industry. Amazon is the top dog in online retail
column21: and it aggressively promotes its Fire TV dongles and smart TVs on its platform. Roku is still beating them all.Roku's enemies are also rivals of Sonos. It was 2005 when Sonos rolled out the first wireless multiroom speaker system
column22: which streams audio seamlessly through a home. Audiophiles flocked to Sonos
column23: but then familiar foes emerged. Apple
column24: Amazon
column25: and Google all had cheap smart speakers in support of their virtual assistant technologies. Sonos was in their crosshairs if they chose to go upmarket
column26: but they missed.Sonos would go on to deliver 17 consecutive years of revenue growth before proving mortal in fiscal 2023. On Tuesday afternoon it posted financial results for the fiscal first quarter of 2024. It was a well-received report.Revenue declined 9%
column27: or 10.5% on a constant-currency basis. It's not pretty
column28: but analysts were bracing for a 13% decline. The bigger surprise is at the other end of the income statement. Profitability improved at Sonos
column29: earning $0.64 a share for the seasonally potent holiday quarter
column30: up from $0.57 a share a year earlier. Wall Street pros were settling for a sharp decline to $0.39 a share.""Despite the challenging environment
column31: we are winning in the market and outperforming the competition
column32: CEO Patrick Spence said in this week's earnings report.Rich in cash and patents
column33: Sonos is well positioned to continue dominating its high-end niche. With analyst profit targets now likely headed higher
column34: Sonos is cheap.Remember when everyone figured that Spotify was toast? The Swedish audio streaming service was making waves worldwide
column35: but would it be able to succeed in the U.S. as Apple Music
column36: Google Play Music
column37: and Amazon Music flooded the market? It's doing pretty well
column38: even if it had to go through three rounds of layoffs last year.There are 602 million mostly ad-supported monthly active users
column39: a 23% increase over the past year. Getting folks to pay is the more difficult nut to crack
column40: but Spotify has been beefing up its catalog of original content to go with its industry-leading music platform. Premium Spotify accounts have risen 15% over the past year to reach 236 million.Apple and Amazon are distant competitors. Google Play Music threw in the towel
column41: handing its digital ambitions over to YouTube Music. It's going to be hard for the other streaming service stocks to catch up to Spotify now.Should you invest $1
column42: 000 in Roku right now?Before you buy stock in Roku

Big Tech’s earnings season has taught us 2 big lessons — so far`"Big Tech’s earnings season is in full swing
column2: and though AI chip giant Nvidia (NVDA) won’t report its results until Feb. 21
column3: there are plenty of insights to glean already. Chief among them is that AI continues to push a huge portion of the conversation for corporate earnings and that fundamental business practices are still important.So far
column4: Alphabet (GOOG
column6: Amazon (AMZN)
column7: AMD (AMD)
column8: Apple (AAPL)
column9: Intel (INTC)
column10: Meta (META)
column11: and Microsoft (MSFT) have largely posted solid reports
column12: but not every company is seeing positive stock moves.Shares of Apple and Google parent Alphabet fell after they reported disappointing sales in their China and advertising businesses
column13: respectively
column14: while shares of Intel and AMD were hammered on lower-than-expected outlooks for the current quarter.Amazon
column15: Meta
column16: and Microsoft
column17: meanwhile
column18: are riding high thanks to big moves in their most important business segments
column19: including consumer sales
column20: advertising
column21: and the cloud.And while it might not seem like it
column22: there are some common threads running through the stock market’s reaction to these earnings reports. From AI investments to advertising and regional sales
column23: Big Tech’s latest earnings have laid out some valuable lessons.If you need more proof that Wall Street’s obsession with AI is still going strong
column24: look no further than how many companies talked up the technology during their earnings calls. Microsoft said its AI offerings added a 6% revenue boost to its Azure cloud business
column25: up from a 3% contribution in the prior quarter
column26: and 1% in the quarter before that. That might not sound like a huge amount
column27: but it allows Microsoft to illustrate that its AI moves are beginning to pay off.UBS analyst Karl Keirstead wrote in an investor note following the company’s earnings that the quarter-over-quarter increase in AI’s growth is proof Azure is seeing a “flow-through of AI demand”’ and a return on capital expenditures.Wedbush analyst Dan Ives
column28: meanwhile
column29: said that Microsoft’s AI-powered Copilots are drawing plenty of interest from enterprise customers. Microsoft’s Copilots are essentially AI-powered apps and include Copilot for Microsoft 365 and the Windows Copilot
column30: which now comes installed on Windows 11 computers.“Copilot conversions appear to be exploding across the MSFT ecosystem as the AI Revolution has begun with partners/customers lining up for the Copilot deployments
column31: ” Ives wrote in a note.Microsoft wasn’t the only company to call out AI. Amazon debuted its new Rufus generative AI shopping bot just ahead of earnings
column32: helping the company better illustrate how generative AI fits into its consumer offerings.Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai also brought up his company’s AI investments at the top of its earnings call
column33: laying out how the technology is being integrated into Google Search
column34: while Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg hit on that company’s AI moves and investments.“If we succeed
column35: everyone who uses our services will have a world-class AI assistant to help get things done
column36: every creator will have an AI that their community can engage with
column37: every business will have an AI that their customers can interact with to buy goods and get support
column38: and every developer will have a state-of-the-art open-source model to build with
column39: ” Zuckerberg said during his company’s earnings call.Intel and AMD
column40: meanwhile
column41: discussed their AI chips and the momentum they’re seeing in the space. Finally
column42: Apple’s Tim Cook revealed that the company is diving deeper into AI with generative AI investments.“We’ve got some things that we are incredibly excited about that we will be [showing] later this year
column43: ” Cook said during the call.""I think there is a huge opportunity for Apple with [generative] AI and AI
column44: he later added in response to an analyst's question.We’ll likely learn more about Apple’s AI moves during its Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) in June. Investors hope the technology will provide a boost to iPhone sales by adding new features that get customers itching to upgrade.While AI continues to drive much of the conversation around Big Tech earnings
column45: this season also taught us that business fundamentals are still key to driving share prices on Wall Street.Alphabet and Apple proved that the hard way.While both companies beat analysts’ expectations on the top and bottom lines
column46: they also missed anticipated revenue in specific business segments. Alphabet fell short on ad revenue in the quarter
column47: posting $65.5 billion versus expectations of $65.8 billion. Alphabet shares dropped following the news.Apple
column49: reported better-than-anticipated earnings and revenue
column51: but the company’s stock took a hit on news that sales in China not only missed expectations but also fell year over year as well.While analysts didn’t seem too concerned about the slowdown in sales in Apple’s third-largest market behind North America and Europe
column52: investors clearly were
column53: as shares went south after the report.Nvidia will be the last of the Big Tech companies to report its earnings
column54: on Feb. 21. Expectations for the company are sky-high after it posted better-than-anticipated earnings in the prior quarter. And if it manages to beat with strong AI sales
column55: it’ll prove both of this earnings season’s lessons true.Daniel Howley is the tech editor at Yahoo Finance. He's been covering the tech industry since 2011. You can follow him on Twitter @DanielHowley.For the latest earnings reports and analysis

column1: 10 Best Stocks To Invest In 2024 For Beginners`"In this article
column2: we discuss 10 best stocks to invest in 2024 for beginners. If you want to skip our detailed discussion on the stock market
column3: head directly to 5 Best Stocks To Invest In 2024 For Beginners. Global stocks reached their highest point in over two years
column4: with the S&P 500 hitting a new record high on February 7
column5: as per Reuters. This was driven by robust earnings
column6: which helped counter concerns surrounding US regional banks and the Chinese markets. Bonds experienced slight pressure
column7: as statements from Federal Reserve officials reinforced the expectation that the central bank might not reduce interest rates in the near future. According to Arthur Hogan
column8: the chief market strategist at B. Riley Wealth: ""We are at the midpoint of the 4Q earnings reporting season
column9: and we would say that there has been more good news than bad.""In 2023
column10: the S&P 500 delivered a total return of 26.29%
column11: recovering from the setback of 18.11% in 2022. In 2024
column12: investors remain optimistic that the same macroeconomic factors driving the stock market's 2023 rally will propel the S&P 500 to achieve new all-time highs. Investors remain hopeful that the Federal Reserve will successfully guide the US economy to a soft landing
column13: transitioning from interest rate hikes to rate cuts. The potential combination of declining interest rates and earnings growth is seen as a positive for stocks. However
column14: analysts express worries about overvalued technology sector stocks
column15: and the upcoming 2024 U.S. presidential election is expected to introduce significant market volatility.Looking at historical data from 1921 to 2023
column16: Sam Stovall

column1: 3 Inspiring Underdogs That Fought Tech Giants and Won`"When it comes to success in emerging industries
column2: size usually matters. Pioneers often fail
column3: leaving behind the foundation for larger players to dominate. Thankfully for investors in mold-breaking upstarts
column4: it doesn't always play out that way.Roku (NASDAQ: ROKU)
column6: and Spotify Technology (NYSE: SPOT) are three companies that saw Apple and other consumer tech behemoths try to take them out. The little guys are not just surviving
column7: but thriving against established titans with almost limitless resources. Take a bow Roku
column8: Sonos
column9: and Spotify.Roku founder Anthony Wood invented the digital video recorder
column10: but it was another company that enjoyed the DVR glory. He got it right when he launched Roku a few years later
column11: pioneering the streaming video revolution. It wasn't long before Roku was joined by some of the most valuable companies on the planet. Apple TV
column12: Alphabet's Google Chromecast
column13: and Amazon's Fire TV hit the market. Roku didn't flinch.Roku remains the leading operating system for smart TVs in the U.S.
column14: Canada
column15: and Mexico. It has roughly double the market share of its closest rival. It doesn't matter that Google and Amazon are willing to practically give away the hardware to get folks connected. Roku has been able to sacrifice product margins
column16: knowing it can make it up in volume.Roku is free to use
column17: making the lion's share of its revenue from ad sharing and referrals. It's working. Average revenue per user is more than $41 over the past year. There are 75.8 million active accounts on the platform
column18: and boy are they active. Roku users are spending an average of 3.8 hours a day streaming through the Roku hub.It doesn't seem possible. Roku is competing against Apple
column19: a company that is used to getting people to pay a premium for its wares. Alphabet is the global leader in online advertising
column20: putting it in the perfect position to cash in on an ad-supported industry. Amazon is the top dog in online retail
column21: and it aggressively promotes its Fire TV dongles and smart TVs on its platform. Roku is still beating them all.Roku's enemies are also rivals of Sonos. It was 2005 when Sonos rolled out the first wireless multiroom speaker system
column22: which streams audio seamlessly through a home. Audiophiles flocked to Sonos
column23: but then familiar foes emerged. Apple
column24: Amazon
column25: and Google all had cheap smart speakers in support of their virtual assistant technologies. Sonos was in their crosshairs if they chose to go upmarket
column26: but they missed.Sonos would go on to deliver 17 consecutive years of revenue growth before proving mortal in fiscal 2023. On Tuesday afternoon it posted financial results for the fiscal first quarter of 2024. It was a well-received report.Revenue declined 9%
column27: or 10.5% on a constant-currency basis. It's not pretty
column28: but analysts were bracing for a 13% decline. The bigger surprise is at the other end of the income statement. Profitability improved at Sonos
column29: earning $0.64 a share for the seasonally potent holiday quarter
column30: up from $0.57 a share a year earlier. Wall Street pros were settling for a sharp decline to $0.39 a share.""Despite the challenging environment
column31: we are winning in the market and outperforming the competition
column32: CEO Patrick Spence said in this week's earnings report.Rich in cash and patents
column33: Sonos is well positioned to continue dominating its high-end niche. With analyst profit targets now likely headed higher
column34: Sonos is cheap.Remember when everyone figured that Spotify was toast? The Swedish audio streaming service was making waves worldwide
column35: but would it be able to succeed in the U.S. as Apple Music
column36: Google Play Music
column37: and Amazon Music flooded the market? It's doing pretty well
column38: even if it had to go through three rounds of layoffs last year.There are 602 million mostly ad-supported monthly active users
column39: a 23% increase over the past year. Getting folks to pay is the more difficult nut to crack
column40: but Spotify has been beefing up its catalog of original content to go with its industry-leading music platform. Premium Spotify accounts have risen 15% over the past year to reach 236 million.Apple and Amazon are distant competitors. Google Play Music threw in the towel
column41: handing its digital ambitions over to YouTube Music. It's going to be hard for the other streaming service stocks to catch up to Spotify now.Should you invest $1
